fields.descriptive_line: Weaver's pattern workbook of drafts and samples with a leather binding to the back, woven by Thomas Palmer, Great Britain, 1786
fields.physical_description:
Weaver's pattern workbook with a leather binding to the back but not the front. The present cover to the front is formed by a sketch in black and red for a diapered pattern, repeated twice. There are seven samples in the book.

Page 3 has a sketch on a smaller scale with four repeats.

p. 5 has a tie for the shafts.

p. 6 has a biblical quotation ending 'So God help thy servant who putteth his trust in thee Thos. Palmer'.

p. 7 has three ties for shafts.

pp. 8-10 has three ties for shafts with a note of colours.

p. 11 has a note of the numbers of threads on shafts and a blue and white sample of diapered linen (loose).

p. 13 'This Draught is Commanly worked with the last sling [sic] on 16 ...'.

p. 14 'Cross and Diamand' with a sample of blue and white linen attached.

pp. 15-18 has draughts

p. 19 'The flower of 4 Diamds'.

'Sling your Gear and Tradles as for Huckaback, tred as you Draw'.

p. 20 'Spoted Pettycoats on 6 leaves & 5 Traddles ...lland, Shrove Tuesday 1787'. There is a sample of blue and white linen on this page with a diapered pattern.

p. 21 'Hit and Miss, tread skipshaft, 4 shots on the 1st & 3rd & 4 on the other two - Red must be Worsted, the other linen'.

p. 22 'Satin stripe for gowns, striped with Green and Red Worsted, and White linen for the Plain work'. The draft has an indication of the colours Red, Green, Red.

p. 23 'The draft and Cording of French Diapers'.

p. 24 'Diamond with Dental Edges'. A sample of blue and white linen is attached which corresponds to this description.

p. 25 'Cut Lincey or Beggars  fustian', and below 'Too Stich Huckaback, Drawerd [?] Skipshaft'.

p. 26 deaft.

p. 27 'French [?] Huckaback' and underneath 'Three stitch huckaback, Sling and Draught' and '2 stitch Huckaback with the same Sling'

p. 28 'Huckaback one 8 leaves, Makes Quarrils Like a Window'.

p. 29 'Thread 5 shoots and tie it down with one shoot then tread the same 5 over again which makes one stich then change to the other Traddles'.

p. 30 Sample of blue and white linen.

p. 31 'Bird Eye Diper for Napkins'. This could be the sample opposite.

p. 32 'Plain Diamande, Draw Backward ... Forward'.

p. 33 'Draught The Grove'.

p. 34 'Holland Diper'.

p. 35 'Dammask rose or Dubble Chaine'.

p. 36 'Carpet. Hammered out of my thick skin Thomum Palmerine [sic]'.

p. 37 'The Trewlovers Knot. Diper'.

p. 38 draft.

p. 39 'Mrs Nickals Barton'. Also between these two pages a sample of blue and white diapered linen.

p. 40 draft.

p. 41 'Cross Spots for Briches', under this 'Dammask Ex & Round 0, on 20'

p. 42 'Birmingham Trencher work'.

p. 43 'Stars & Diamands' / 'Diamande & Birds Eye' [set out like this with a line between].

p. 44 'Hearts and Diamands [space] Baskit work' 'Draw streetover & Back again'.

p. 45 'Draughts on 15 Diper, sling the same as the last' and under this 'Draught on 12 Carpet'

p. 46 'Draught of the Brittish Rose, Sling as above'.

p. 47 'Dubble Sink & Cato' and under this 'Rib'd Dimothy for waiscoats'. Dimity should be a linen and cotton mixture.

p. 48 'Trail Huckaback on 8' and under this 'Half Inch diaper'

p. 49 'The Trewlovers knot, Coverlid' and under this 'Irish Counterpain'

p. 50 '...ut of a Chaise Ashby-de-la-Zouche'.

p. 51 'Jos. Hallam Ashby, Carpet'.

p. 52 'Tie upon 16 Carpet' and ' Draught below'

p. 53 'Draughts upon 3 Devisions Carpet'. There is a sample of diapered unbleached linen between pp. 52 and 53.

p. 54 'Bed Rugs Clubs and Diamonds' and 'Carpet'

p. 55 'Thomas Palmer / Work Book 1786'
fields.dimensions: Height: 5.625 in, Height: 14.3 cm, Width: 3.75 in, Width: 9.6 cm, Thickness: 2 cm spine, Weight: 0.08 kg

fields.history_note:
Registered File number 1988/474.

The draughts could almost certainly be interpreted by a handweaver. The names given to the weavers were, presumably, well-known among linen weavers of the time. Few such books have survived but the terminology resembles weaving draft books which have survived in the USA. A comparison could be fruitful.

The book had belonged to the donor's aunt Miss Lilian Harris, who was interested in spinning and weaving and joined a group of weavers (possibly the Guild of Weavers Spinners and Dyers, West Kent Branch?). Miss Harris died in 1971 and the book was found among other items of interest to weavers in a case. This case had belonged to the previous tenant of Miss Harris' house, Miss Mary Somerville. The house had belonged to a Mrs Heron Maxwell, also a weaver. The family assumed that the book had belonged either to Miss Somerville or Mrs Maxwell. None of these people had any connection with any family named Palmer or with Ashby-de-la-Zouche.
